channel.title: Comments on: SQL Server does support regular expressions in check constraints, triggers are not always needed
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Alan
item.dc:creator: Alan
item.content:encoded:
I know I am a little late to the game here but I just published an article on how to create CHECK constraints using regular expressions (the .NET flavor).

http://xmlsqlninja.blogspot.com/2013/09/mdqregex-clr-functions-part-3-regex.html

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.description: I agree, I have seen code that runs once an hour to convert NULLs to 0.......why not make the column not null instead or put a constraint that checks that the column is greater or equal to 0
item.content:encoded: I agree, I have seen code that runs once an hour to convert NULLs to 0…….why not make the column not null instead or put a constraint that checks that the column is greater or equal to 0

item.title: By: sqlsister
item.dc:creator: sqlsister
item.description: People so often forget about check constraints entirely
item.content:encoded: People so often forget about check constraints entirely

item.title: By: traingamer
item.dc:creator: traingamer
item.description: Nice - a clean, clear explanation using 'like'.
